body:
On of the goals of neovim project is the modernization of the build system. The chosen cmake makes it easy to generate project files and configurations for different systems and tool chains. But instead of normalizing the handling of the build system, we introduce the following hierarchy:
- **make** - which cannot be replaced by Ninja or other tools, to many cleanups
  - **other Makefiles** - 
  - **cmake** - should be on the top, changing config required Makefile modification
  - **handcrafted scripts** - which parse some stuff and do things and a serial and non-abstract way, lot of redundant code
    - **build systems of 3rd-party libs**
  - **tests** - called in a serial way, handcrafted, output not parsable, Makefile driven but contains a lot of shell script stuff

Instead of improving it, we introduced a lot of new scripts and more jumping-around stuff the last days. I recommend improving the situation using the following strategy:
1. replace top-level Makefile by cmake code (even when it's only some-script calls)
2. decouple tests/build/config
3. move scripts into cmake and replace many calls by cmake-directives
4. port over test to CTest

comment_data.body:
If a pure cmake solution for building the project and it's dependencies proves to be simpler I don't see why not. 

Except for item '4'. I completely disagree with using CMake or C to write tests. Scripting languages are much simpler to use and luajit's ffi module let us talk with C code almost transparently. I've just pushed an [example](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/unit/misc1.moon) and will soon write documentation that will help contributors write their own tests.

Moonscript will probably be used for writing functional tests when the msgpack UI is ready

@tarruda CTest doesn't require that you write tests in C.  It simply requires a test runner that returns 0 when it passes, and non-zero when a test fails.  Believe it or not, you probably want to be using it.

Sorry I mistaked this for a PR. too many browser tabs open :)

@jszakmeister I dont object with what @crepererum proposed, as long as it doesn't complicate setting up new development environments(as in having to download and install less common dependencies manually). I want neovim to be a very easy project to contribute.

CTest comes with CMake, so it doesn't add anything there.  Plus, CMake has facilities to download files, so you could get rid of the need to have wget or curl.

FWIW, I agree with the @crepererum--we should strive to push what we can into CMake.  And I think it can all be done while keeping it easy for others to contribute too.
@crepererum @jszakmeister what would `CTest` offer over the current `busted` tests? I've never used CTest, so I'm just asking. I think the busted infrastructure is quite ok, actually.

@aktau That's hard for me to answer--I have no idea what `busted` offers.  Here's the feature list from CMake's site:
- Run all or sub-sets of tests for a project
- Submit testing results to Dart 1,2 and CDash
- Run tests that build and run --build-and-test command
- support coverage with gcc, and bullseye coverage tools
- support memory checking with valgrind, purify, and bounds checker

I think one really nice feature is that it doesn't care about what language was used.  It simply needs to be executable, and return a non-zero exit code on error, and 0 on success.  So you could have tests that require C (for some reason), some written in shell (like the current test driver for Vim's tests), or something else.  I'm pretty sure `busted` only does Lua based tests, so you kind of miss out on the other stuff.  That said, there's nothing to stop us from driving the unit tests with `busted` and tying everything together with CTest.

My only real concern in bringing it up was that I wanted to break the misconception that CTest somehow requires C.  It does not.

> CTest comes with CMake, so it doesn't add anything there. Plus, CMake has facilities to download files, so you could get rid of the need to have wget or curl

It might be a good idea to wait before we become even more dependent on cmake.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/41 raised the issue of moving away from cmake completely, by some gentoo upstream devs who probably have some valuable insight.
I've been using CMake for quite a while now, and in a cross-compile environment.  It's fine.  _shrug_

@jszakmeister no, it is not at all.

The problems of cmake are that does not work out of box for cross compiling, does require cmake on every system building neovim and the amount of features available is even LESS than autotools, making the traditional "autotools is broken because who wrote the configure.ac is clueless" plague even more likely.

the so loathed autotools provides a quite simple and easy way to support tests and uses the standard TAP paradigm, making easy integrating it with additional reporting and such.

If you want bleeding edge there are sufficiently new stuff such as automake 2 (traditionally well hidden in the gnu mailing lists)

if autotools sucks, cmake sucks as well and in ways that make my life as distributor worse.

@lu-zero You are certainly free to disagree, but I've dealt with the autotools hell as well--it's a complicated mess.  It's hard to avoid being "clueless" when writing configure.ac.  I'll give it credit that it has largely solved the problem of building for a ton of different systems, but it is painful to maintain.

Perhaps you've learned all the nuances being a package manager--how to invoke the beast without suffering the wrath--but I've not, despite many hours struggling with autoconf, automake, and libtool in a great many situations.  As I said in the other thread, it's easy to invoke--which you as a package maintainer appreciate--but it's not easy at all to wrap your head around.

I don't want bleeding edge, and certainly not bleeding edge of any autoconf tool.

If cmake sucks, then autotools sucks as well and in ways that makes my life as developer worse. :-)

@jszakmeister I'm here to help in this regard.

Some [documentation](https://www.flameeyes.eu/autotools-mythbuster/) makes managing autotools in an effective way and I'd maintain the neovim build system if you move away from cmake (since I'd rather not have yet another project using cmake)

neovim is not webkit (that literally makes evident the defects and corner cases of gnu make) nor libreoffice (with plenty of weird deps).

neovim has probably 5 deps in total all of them using [pkgconf](https://github.com/pkgconf/pkgconf/blob/master/pkg.m4), making that part a single standard line to add one of them.

As said, I can prepare an autotools-based build system quickly and make it clean enough so you can see if it would be a pain.

I'm sure cmake is a pain to me since my problems are in the core cmake, not the fact somebody got wrong how to use it.

> neovim is not webkit (that literally makes evident the defects and corner cases of gnu make) nor libreoffice (with plenty of weird deps).

No, it is not.  But seconds count and Ninja saves them.  Plus, developers don't need to know to pass `-j N` to make to get a speedier build.  The difference with using Ninja is at least ten-fold on a Windows box--starting a process on Windows is much longer than on Linux box, make starts many of them.

Sorry, I'm just not convinced that we should have developers suffer that penalty to make packaging easier for Linux.  What about packaging on Windows?  What about packaging on the Mac--an actual DMG file that users can use to install, not Homebrew?  CMake helps on all those fronts, autotools does not.

> neovim has probably 5 deps in total all of them using pkgconf, making that part a single standard line to add one of them.

Dependencies are only half the story.  What about building on Windows with the MSVC toolchain?  There's no hope of doing that without mingw/msys/cygwin, which just slows down the build more.  Again, building for Linux is not the only consideration.  It may appear that way now because the project is bootstrapping itself, but it's not going to stay that way.

> As said, I can prepare an autotools-based build system quickly and make it clean enough so you can see if it would be a pain.
> 
> I'm sure cmake is a pain to me since my problems are in the core cmake, not the fact somebody got wrong how to use it.

Then why not try to address those issues with the CMake team?

How many neovim developers use windows? how many users use windows? Neovim
is too small to make a difference of seconds from make to ninja...

The project is just bootstrapping itself... I don't think we have _any_ users. :-)

Are you saying that we should pick a tool that won't work on well Windows because we don't currently have any users on Windows?  Windows developers have enough issues without us making it more complicated for them. :-)

``` console
$ cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -G "Unix Makefiles" ..
# ... snipped ...
$ time make                                 
Scanning dependencies of target nvim
# ... snipped ...
[100%] Built target nvim-test
make  39.49s user 11.40s system 94% cpu 53.701 total
$ rm -rf .* *
$ cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -G "Unix Makefiles" ..
# ... snipped ...
$ time make -j$(grep -c ^processor /proc/cpuinfo)
Scanning dependencies of target nvim
# ... snipped ...
[100%] Built target nvim-test
make -j$(grep -c ^processor /proc/cpuinfo)  38.09s user 11.79s system 179% cpu 27.802 total
$ rm -rf .* * 
$ cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -G Ninja ..           
# ... snipped ...
$ time ninja
[106/106] Linking C shared module src/libnvim-test.so
ninja  37.12s user 9.96s system 191% cpu 24.597 total
```

There you have it.  Ninja: 24.6 seconds, bare make: 53.7s, make -j2: 27.8 seconds.

We can debate this all day long, and we both have equally compelling reasons.  I'm not going to convince you CMake is fine, and you aren't going to convince me that autotools are a better solution.  But it's already been decided that we're sticking with CMake.

Thanks again for the link to the Autotools Mythbuster.  I do appreciate your input, and I've learned something from the debate.

@jszakmeister wow, so it does take a decent amount of time for you.

With ccache:

``` bash
$ make clean && make cmake CMAKE_EXTRA_FLAGS="-DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=clang"
$ which clang
/usr/local/opt/ccache/libexec/clang
...
$ time make
...
[100%] Built target nvim
[100%] Built target nvim-test
nice -n 3 make -j$(sysctl -n hw.ncpu)  3,55s user 2,30s system 346% cpu 1,688 total
```

Without ccache:

``` bash
$ make clean && make cmake CMAKE_EXTRA_FLAGS="-DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=/usr/local/bin/clang"
$ time make
...
Linking C executable ../bin/nvim
[100%] Built target nvim
Linking C shared module libnvim-test.so
[100%] Built target nvim-test
nice -n 3 make -j$(sysctl -n hw.ncpu)  62,60s user 6,22s system 697% cpu 9,871 total
```

This is actually why I clean/config/make all the time, it just doesn't take very long. Especially with ccache, hopefully it stays that way.

As for the issue at hand: I don't really have any problem with cmake, but I don't plan on developing the build system, just use it. I usually use plain make and pkg-config, but that's not very portable to windows (msvc at least) so that won't work in the case of vim. I mean, we're dropping a lot of platforms but definitely not the big 4 (win, linux, osx, freebsd).

I do have one input of an example that's possible to follow (though I don't recommend it):

[nanomsg](https://github.com/nanomsg/nanomsg) has both a cmake and autoconf-based build system. It started out with a very simple and clean cmake-based one, which I quite liked. But I believe someone (probably a distro maintainer) convinced them that autoconf was way better for unices and offered to do the build system. So now they have both systems, because they don't want to drop msvc support, which is understandable. This does mean maintaining a double system and changing the build system a bit becomes a whole ordeal.

@aktau It is slow without ccache, yes.  With ccache it's much better:

``` console
$ time ninja
[106/106] Linking C shared module src/libnvim-test.so
ninja  0.88s user 1.19s system 127% cpu 1.626 total
```

With make as the engine:

``` console
$ time make -j$(grep -c ^processor /proc/cpuinfo)
[100%] Built target nvim
[100%] Built target nvim-test
make -j$(grep -c ^processor /proc/cpuinfo)  1.94s user 3.89s system 117% cpu 4.953 total
```

My machine is a bit behind the times (quad-core 2.66GHz with 13GB of memory), but I think it's comparable to others.

In my case:

ninja from cmake

```
real    0m4.404s
user    0m29.046s
sys     0m2.720s
```

make -j 4 from cmake

```
real    0m5.728s
user    0m19.860s
sys     0m2.282s
```

make -j 8

```
real    0m4.493s
user    0m28.675s
sys     0m3.038s
```

And probably using a less bloated build rules in ninja and make would speed everything up a little more... (so no, for me cmake-generated ninja or make rules aren't that different)

Fwiw, I use Windows heavily, in addition to linux and mac. Suggesting that Windows users can be an afterthought is a loss of credibility for the autotools camp. And it defeats the purpose of neovim, which is supposed to improve vim, not regress it.

@justinmk No one actually suggested that, and I don't believe @lu-zero doesn't care.  He just sees what he believes is a better path to get things packaged and distributed for the *nix masses, and has felt the pain of packaging CMake projects.  It's a fair criticism.

@lu-zero If it's easy enough, would it be better to just include a `configure.ac` along side the CMake infrastructure instead of replacing it?  If it's not hard to maintain, then it might be worth while.

notifications@github.comwrote:

> better to just include a configure.ac along side the CMake infrastructure
> instead of replacing it? If it's not hard to maintain, then it might be

> 
> It is feasible, as said neovim doesn't seem to require a lot of special
